newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Oct 29.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - South Africa - Oct 29.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Tuesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Reserve Bank governor Chris Stals reiterated assurances that South Africa would follow the right policies as the rand crashed through records against the dollar and the pound.
- Malbak shareholders could be in for a fillip of at least one billion rand over the market value of the shares they receive from the unbundling of the consumer group.
- Off-peak domestic air travel is at its cheapest since 1991 after an airfare war broke out between SAA and British Airways-Comair.
- Parastatal Transnet waived normal tendering procedures in awarding a multi-million rand scrap metal contract to curb theft and promote black economic empowerment.
- The embattled rand hit record lows against the dollar and the pound fuelling speculation that it could soon reach five rand to the dollar.
- Oil company Engen improved substantially on last year's dismal performance by posting a 201 percent rise in net income for the year to August 31 of 349 million rand.
- The U.S. commerce department has identified South Africa as a preferred emerging market with special growth potential, officials in the South African embassy in Washington said.
- Commercial airline Comair went a step further than SAA and slashed prices to an all-time low for an indefinite period.
- An independent inquiry into irregularities in the Gauteng province matric exams is to be launched by the province's Education MEC, Mary Metcalfe.
- A second front has developed in the fighting in eastern Zaire and an estimated 800,000 people are now displaced in the region.
